newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul to probe finance institutions' debt demands.
newsitem.headline: Seoul to probe finance institutions' debt demands.

text.p: South Korea's Finance and Economy Minister said on Friday the government would investigate moves by financial institutions to call in corporate debts or refuse fresh loans for no reason.

In a luncheon meeting with representatives of secondary financial institutions, Kang Kyong-shik said he would establish a special centre to hear companies' complaints of "unreasonable" demands by financial institutions.
Kang criticised domestic financial institutions for moving too quickly to call in debts of companies rumoured to be in trouble.
Merchant banks in particular have been unwilling to shoulder any of the burden of troubled corporates, he said, preferring to shift the burden of helping companies stay afloat to banks.
Kang said this eagerness to act on rumours had triggered severe cash-flow problems among domestic companies, even though the money market had remained stable.

"This is forcing banks to undertake the entire responsibility of providing credit, which will lead banks to default in the long run," Kang said. "This will cause a financial crisis and lead to serious economic trouble."
All financial institutions should get together voluntarily to work out an action plan, he said.
Kang asked secondary finance institutions to cooperate with a voluntary bank committee established in March to keep troubled corporates in business.
The current situation stemmed from financial institutions' "excessively strict" application of loan terms since the recent string of corporate failures, he said.
Kang urged secondary institutions not to drastically curtail credits on the basis of rumours or unsubstantiated information.
"Financial institutions should notify companies one or two weeks in advance if they intend to stop extending fresh loans," Kang said.
When a company goes bankrupt its management know-how, trained personnel resources and external recognition would be lost, he said. "This would create a great loss to the economy."
